H0.text: Decomposition is the process that converts organic nitrogen into an inorganic form that can be used by plants.

H1.text: Sedimentation is the process that converts organic nitrogen into an inorganic form that can be used by plants.

H2.text: Absorption is the process that converts organic nitrogen into an inorganic form that can be used by plants.

H3.text: Radiation is the process that converts organic nitrogen into an inorganic form that can be used by plants.

A4.text: Bacteria and fungi convert this organic nitrogen into ammonia and sometimes ammonium through a series of processes called ammonification or mineralization.

A5.text: Plants can absorb nitrate or ammonium from the soil by their root hairs.

A6.text: The nitrogenous wastes in animal urine are broken down by nitrifying bacteria in the soil to be used by plants.

A7.text: These multiply, consuming the body's carbohydrates, lipids and proteins, to produce a variety of substances including propionic acid, lactic acid, methane, hydrogen sulfide and ammonia.
